Funding for Current

7.51.text:
OU OUtreach,
and World Literature Today.

18.82.text:
at the National Conference
on Race and Ethnicity

23.42.text:
We will be talking about
race and indigenous culture

26.59.text:
with our special guest Sedelta
Oosahwee

30.40.text:
a former senior advisor at the
U.S. Department of Agriculture

33.03.text:
and now a policy analyst with
Tribal Tech.

36.47.text:
She works with issues relating
to rural development,

42.71.text:
Stay with us and
meet this important

64.56.text:
It is great to have
you here.

66.40.text:
You have just a
really interesting career

72.77.text:
and now I think you are
with an organization

78.08.text:
maybe start with your
trial identification,

80.51.text:
talk about that a little
bit if you wouldn’t mind

82.42.text:
and then maybe a
few things about your career.

85.29.text:
OOSAHWEE: Okay. So, I grew up
in Tahlequah, Oklahoma.

87.49.text:
I am an enrolled citizen of
the three affiliated tribes

90.72.text:
there at Fort Berthold,
North Dakota.

93.19.text:
I had a really - I didn’t
realize it at the time,

95.50.text:
but I had a really unique
upbringing.

98.30.text:
My mom grew up on this
reservation community

100.77.text:
My dad is a Cherokee speaker
that grew up in Tahlequah,

104.20.text:
So, I had these two
perspectives

106.21.text:
of what it meant to be
Native and indigenous,

108.98.text:
and that really kind of helped
shape and form who I am today.

111.51.text:
I went to the
University of Oklahoma

118.69.text:
I loved it so much I went on
to graduate school there.

119.95.text:
And so after that I ended
up in education

122.32.text:
which is something I never
wanted to do.

125.53.text:
OOSAHWEE: My mom is kind
of an educator, my dad.

127.96.text:
Everyone in my family I felt
like were educators,

129.40.text:
and I said, “I am going
to do something different.”

131.20.text:
I want to make my
own path,

132.63.text:
and I ended up in a graduate
program in education

134.37.text:
and working at Northeastern
State University in Tahlequah,

136.34.text:
and I realized
that I love education.

141.31.text:
OOSAHWEE: I guess it is
probably in your blood.

142.88.text:
I think it is one of those
things where my family,

144.61.text:
there is a reason we are
all drawn to this.

146.08.text:
OOSAHWEE: Because I
think it is just something

147.78.text:
that we enjoy 
and we are good at,

149.25.text:
and so I was there
for a few years,

150.92.text:
but I kind of recognized
that I wanted

152.39.text:
to do a little
bit more for my community

153.85.text:
and my students and started
reaching out.

155.42.text:
I ended up being invited to a
position in D.C.

160.23.text:
Somebody called me out of the
blue and said,

162.23.text:
“Hey, we need somebody to be
legislative assistant

164.30.text:
at this firm that we own,
are you interested?

166.30.text:
Um, I went ahead and
did an interview

169.47.text:
and they offered me
the position

172.24.text:
and I had never really
thought about living in D.C.

174.57.text:
I was very content in
Oklahoma.

176.08.text:
I thought I would be like my
mom and dad, you know.

177.84.text:
I would work at the
university,

180.01.text:
have a family, and that is what
you do in life.

181.58.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: It’s got to be
a culture shock

183.28.text: going to a place like D.C.

184.42.text:
OOSAHWEE: (Laugh) it was
absolute, total culture shock.

186.42.text:
I’m not even- that first night
I got there,

188.22.text:
I had just finished my first
day of work,

190.16.text:
and I got to my room,
and I thought,

194.63.text:
OOSAHWEE: And I think I
probably cried that night,

195.80.text:
because “I’m like, I don’t
know what I am doing here.”

197.50.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: People talk
about the pressure cooker

201.64.text:
And just not knowing anyone,
not knowing my bearings.

203.84.text:
But when I was
offered the position

205.17.text: I knew I had to take it

206.21.text:
because it was a very unique
once in a lifetime opportunity.

208.64.text:
I think that has kind
of been my story

210.44.text:
of these opportunities
that have presented themselves

212.28.text:
and I’ve just had to say
yes to them you know,

215.12.text:
and if I hadn’t said yes to
one of those,

217.02.text:
I wouldn’t be where I am
right now.

219.02.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: So this was
a corporation initially.

221.05.text:
OOSAHWEE: It was a
lobbying firm.

224.79.text:
OOSAHWEE: They lobbied on
behalf of tribes,

226.43.text:
and so that was a really
interesting environment too.

228.50.text:
Just to learn about how that
works

230.40.text:
and what it looks like
and how complicated it is.

233.03.text:
Did that give you the
connections that led you to be

235.37.text:
in the U.S. Department
of Agriculture?

237.04.text: OOSAHWEE: It did. So, it did.

238.21.text:
I actually met so many people
in that year.

240.24.text:
There is a small tribal
community there,

243.51.text:
I was in D.C.
for a year

245.15.text:
and actually moved
back to Oklahoma

247.81.text:
OOSAHWEE: They were
during this transition.

249.28.text:
When I came back
during that time,

250.75.text:
but about six months, and then
I kind of realized

253.95.text:
and I felt like I had left a
little too early.

255.52.text:
Which is weird because I
missed home when I was in D.C.

259.93.text:
OOSAHWEE: Total, yeah, I think
I kind of romanticized home

264.46.text:
My family is there, and I will
always come back,

265.83.text:
but I felt like I needed to do
a little bit more,

267.70.text:
and I had the tools
to do more.

269.37.text:
So, I reached out to people
that I met that first time

272.37.text:
and said, “Hey, I am interested,
do you see anything?”

274.21.text:
And my first position
was actually

275.64.text:
with the White House
Initiative on American Indian

279.05.text:
I was appointed the associate
director there.

280.75.text:
So, friends recommended me to
the current,

285.22.text:
the director at the time
and he reached out and said

290.59.text:
but we are trying to
fill this position,

292.86.text:
and we are seeking
out people."

293.93.text:
So, I sent it in not knowing
what would happen

295.50.text:
and I had a
phone interview,

297.86.text:
and then I was offered
the position.

300.57.text:
with your background,
to do that?

302.60.text:
Because just so often indigenous
people talk about feeling-

305.84.text:
I may be at odds
with the Federal Government,

309.24.text:
and so here you
were an insider suddenly.

313.78.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: So what was
that like?

315.02.text:
OOSAHWEE: You know, people have
asked me that over the past.

316.62.text:
Especially with the Dakota
Access Pipeline

318.35.text:
and the things that
were happening

319.95.text:
over the last,
you know, year.

321.72.text:
How do you kind of, I guess,
reconcile the two?

323.89.text:
But what I have come to
realize and understand

327.59.text:
is that I was working from
within the system

331.16.text:
OOSAHWEE: Which is one of the
most complicated

334.53.text:
and sometimes physically
and emotionally trying things

337.84.text:
I had no idea how complicated
the system was,

340.07.text:
But, I also recognized that we
weren’t present

341.78.text: in so many times and places.

345.58.text:
That system wasn’t created or
designed for or by us,

348.32.text:
and so our perspectives
weren’t incorporated

352.35.text:
and we were kind of after
thoughts.

353.92.text:
And so it was a
matter of, like,

355.26.text:
learning all of these
different things

356.69.text:
and how do we
make it more,

357.79.text:
how do we make it
better for tribes

360.29.text:
and for our communities and
have better representation?

362.23.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: Did this hurt
you back home?

366.07.text:
that you were in
a job like that.

367.13.text:
I mean you’ve got - your
explaining the rationale

369.54.text:
for what you are
trying to do.

370.57.text:
But I can imagine that wasn’t
always translatable

375.38.text:
I think most of them were
actually proud

377.18.text:
and really happy for me.
DAVIS-UNDIANO: Okay.

380.25.text:
the Obama administration was
incredible for tribes.

384.08.text:
there are all these little
things that happened

384.72.text:
and most people
don’t know about,

387.82.text:
and we may not recognize you
know for years to come,

389.06.text:
and one thing that I think is
really powerful

391.09.text:
is that he included us in the
conversation.

392.43.text:
He mentioned us in his
speeches.

394.06.text:
He had positions
created for us

398.00.text:
I talked to a lot of young
people during that time,

399.83.text:
and I wanted them
to know.

401.13.text:
I said, “You have to
understand that this is unique.

403.14.text:
When I was growing up a
president never said tribes,

405.87.text:
didn’t talk to us, didn’t come
to our communities.

409.01.text:
and the fact that you
have someone in this position

412.91.text:
going into your
communities and asking you

414.45.text:
to come in and see
him is amazing

415.65.text:
and now you
know what that feels like.

417.68.text:
But, you also have to understand
that that can go away."

419.49.text:
As quickly as it comes, it
can go away and so we have

423.59.text:
to always make sure that we
are voting for people

425.59.text:
and looking for people
who do that.

427.99.text:
But I think what is really
interesting is that

430.20.text:
they are going to
grow up in a world

431.90.text:
where that
is normal and okay,

435.27.text:
and one of the things
that was most incredible to me

437.50.text:
was that she allowed me
to grow up in a time

439.47.text:
thinking it was normal
for a woman to be chief.

441.07.text:
Because when I was a child
she was chief.

442.54.text:
And I was like oh,
women are chief.

445.78.text:
I think for our community,
oh yeah,

446.95.text:
you can be a black man and
be president.

450.15.text:
OOSAHWEE: And that is really
empowering for them.

451.65.text:
So, I really look
forward to seeing

453.15.text:
what all of these young
people who interacted with him

456.02.text:
or Michelle or other people
in administration,

457.96.text:
what they are
going to do.

459.36.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: So that was a
good time for you.

461.66.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: You felt you
were advancing the good.

464.96.text:
OOSAHWEE: Yeah, yeah, it was a
golden age for me.

466.53.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO:
So you in a word

468.47.text:
were a victim of political
transformation,

473.04.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: So Tribal Tech,
what is that?

474.57.text:
OOSAHWEE: So Tribal Tech.
We have different contracts

478.31.text:
So, we know we have a contract
with the Office of Indian Ed

480.61.text:
to help administer some of
their programs and outreach.

482.78.text:
We have one at the Office
of Energy,

486.89.text:
and they have two with
Health and Human Services.

492.63.text:
OOSAHWE: And the other one is
with the SAMSA,

496.30.text:
I can’t remember all of it,
I apologize,

498.10.text:
but it’s kind of a new agency
for me to be working with,

500.13.text:
but I contract and help with the
SAMSA contract that they have.

503.40.text:
And so they have
this thing

506.01.text:
called a Tribal
Technical Advisory center,

510.01.text:
and if they have problems
or issues, you know,

511.85.text:
we have someone that
does an inventory

514.88.text:
and we provide
training for them.

515.92.text:
So, one of the things that we
provide is this training

519.09.text:
which is this
incredible training module

522.92.text:
and trauma in the form
of caring and healing.

524.59.text:
And so I am going to get to go
and participate

526.19.text:
in my first GONA training in a
couple, I guess in July,

528.06.text:
and so I am really excited
about that.

530.40.text:
Everyone that I have known has
gone through it

532.03.text:
and has nothing
but praise for it

533.73.text:
and so it is really cool
to learn about this agency

535.47.text:
that is doing so much for
our tribes and communities

537.64.text:
that maybe people
don’t know about

539.64.text:
and to hear them say stuff
like trauma informed care

543.51.text:
and how do we
address that?

545.35.text:
And those are not words
and concepts

547.18.text:
that you usually hear from the
Federal Government.

549.22.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: Historical
trauma, people are talking

550.58.text:
about that more and that just
seems like

552.12.text:
such an important -
OOSAHWEE: And they are

554.62.text:
Yeah, and they actually
actively support that work.

555.99.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: You just show
so much strength and flexibility

558.36.text:
in everything that you do,
and so ften to be ignored -

567.47.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: By the culture
at large.

573.51.text:
that happened to you as a child
where you saw,

575.11.text:
well, I could do work like this,
I could make a difference.

576.81.text:
Was there a role model maybe
with Wilma Mankiller, you know,

579.11.text:
where do you, where
did you draw the strength from?

580.78.text:
OOSAHWEE: I think I just drew
it from my family,

586.45.text:
Um, they were just incredibly
strong resilient human beings.

588.56.text:
I mean they are just
incredible people

591.83.text:
and that strength I think
has kind of carried me

593.83.text:
through in different
places and areas.

597.66.text:
I know my dad was one
of eight.

600.80.text:
My mom was one
of eleven.

602.50.text:
My mom was in
boarding school.

604.30.text:
My dad had to
learn English

605.61.text:
when he went to
the public school system,

607.91.text:
and so they all
overcame so much,

609.71.text:
and my parents both went on to
get college degrees

612.25.text:
and so that was an expectation
that was set for us.

615.55.text:
I just assumed that you
go to high school,

618.55.text:
then you go to college,
and then you get a job

620.89.text:
and that was an incredible
expectation set by my parents

626.43.text:
and everything that they
have overcome,

627.53.text:
I think just kind of
carried me through

628.76.text:
and it has been one
of the greatest gifts

631.30.text:
that they have ever
given me.

632.67.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: You are a-
somebody that works under,

635.20.text:
I would say, under the umbrella
of social justice

638.34.text:
and to be somebody so clear
minded and strong as you are

641.71.text:
you have to work some of
those things out so that you,

643.68.text:
you know what your own
version of social justice is,

650.22.text:
Would you share that
with us?

651.95.text:
I mean how do you think
of social justice

655.42.text:
OOSAHWEE: Well, I
think that social justice

657.32.text:
has become this kind of
buzz word and a hashtag

659.03.text:
and I am not sure that everyone
really is on the same page

660.59.text:
to think of what is
social justice?

664.46.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: It doesn’t get
defined very much.

666.03.text:
OOSAHWEE: No, no one, people
don’t really define it.

668.90.text:
OOSAHWEE: I think that I kind
of have to laugh

672.71.text:
I think James Brown
kind of said,

674.07.text:
“I don’t want you to give
me nothing,

675.48.text:
open the door and I will
get it myself.“

676.94.text:
And that is kind of the way
I feel about social justice.

678.68.text:
It is like this recognition
that doors are closed to people

680.95.text:
and how do we open them
and let’s open those doors.

684.78.text:
we haven’t had access
to so many things

686.22.text:
and our voice
hasn’t been at the table

688.35.text:
or part of the conversation
for so long

689.96.text:
so, it is a matter
of being at the table

691.99.text:
and trying to be a
reflection of that.

693.73.text:
But, a lot of the work was
educating people

696.50.text:
and reminding them
tribes still exist.

699.77.text:
We are different than other
communities and here is how,

701.97.text:
and you need to work
with us differently.

704.17.text:
But, the fact that we
were there

707.84.text:
and tell people that was
so powerful

709.54.text:
and it opened doors for
people in communities.

711.31.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: The question I
am going to ask now

714.58.text:
could be a whole other show but
I am going to ask it anyway.

718.22.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: You know, we
could think about

719.99.text:
sort of the dual original
sins of the United States

721.72.text:
as slavery and then
Indian removal.

724.89.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: And it feels like
maybe we get a little closer

726.99.text:
dealing with historical
trauma with slavery.

730.43.text:
The culture doesn’t seem to be
very close to dealing with

735.10.text:
indigenous issues, and they
need to be dealt with.

739.27.text:
I mean it has never been a
Supreme Court -

741.91.text:
Indigenous Supreme Court
Justice for example.

744.21.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: You can just go
on with that list way-

747.11.text:
Why aren’t we closer
on that?

750.22.text:
It would just seem like to be
a no brainer;

751.85.text:
we need to talk about
our past.

754.35.text:
Um, I think it is because we
are just invisible.

755.99.text: Part of it is just statistics.

758.19.text:
You know, we are such a small
percentage of the population,

760.13.text:
and most people never have
interactions

764.20.text:
A lot of the time it is only
through a mascot

766.20.text:
or some other kind of
demeaning way

767.90.text:
that any kind of context point
for native people.

769.37.text:
You know we were at this
screening last night,

772.67.text:
More Than a Word,
this incredible documentary

774.81.text:
and there was a Q
and A afterward,

776.91.text:
and one of the
people said,

778.44.text:
“I just didn’t know
this was an issue”

779.68.text:
and my friend looked
at me and said,

781.05.text:
“How do they not know
that this is an issue?”

782.35.text:
And I told her that
because they don’t -

784.15.text:
we live in a different
universe.

786.32.text:
As a kid, I thought everyone
was Native American.

790.09.text:
because I grew up in
Tahlequah, Oklahoma.

793.46.text:
When I went up to
North Dakota,

794.69.text:
I would pick up my aunt in
Nebraska and my cousin,

799.00.text:
and I have people in
Minneapolis and Montana,

802.70.text:
I just assumed we were
all Indian, you know?

803.80.text: And I remember as a kid

805.74.text:
I was looking at a
history book one summer

807.54.text:
because I was a nerd and
I read all of the time

809.18.text:
and I was like, population,
it says we are less than 1%.

812.48.text:
So, I walked up to my mom
and said,

814.08.text:
“Mom, it says 1%,"
and she was like,

817.28.text:
Like she is wrong on this too,
which is crazy.

819.69.text:
that I realized that that
bubble that I had lived in,

821.32.text:
and I think we have this
social media bubble now.

824.79.text:
Because all of my friends
are very active

827.16.text:
and they have all
of these issues.

828.80.text:
They are always coming up on
my timeline and my feed.

831.16.text:
But, if you don’t
have anyone in your life

835.87.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: You know, I think
you are talking about something

839.57.text:
that there are millions
of Americans,

840.97.text:
and I am going to say this,
but I think it is true,

843.28.text:
who have either never met a
black person or never known,

846.75.text:
and possibly never met an
indigenous person.

849.95.text:
Millions, and that is a
problem.

851.55.text:
OOSAHWEE: Yeah, that is a
huge problem.

853.45.text:
DAVIS, UNDIANO: That is a huge
problem right there.

855.09.text:
OOSAHWEE: That is one of the
biggest problems I see

857.06.text:
and I kind of ask people that
if you don’t understand

858.46.text:
this Black Lives
Matter, you know,

860.33.text:
if you have no one in your life
who truly and honestly fears

861.99.text:
when they send their
child out,

864.53.text:
out the door what could
happen to them.

866.73.text:
If you don’t know
anyone in their life

868.07.text:
who is honestly afraid of
interactions

870.44.text:
with police officers because
of the outcomes of so many.

872.64.text:
If you have no one in your
life that has that perspective,

878.01.text:
and that is something that you
might want to consider.

881.45.text:
But we are segregated in so
many ways.

885.02.text:
through schools, which are a
huge problem,

886.35.text:
you can live your whole life
and never have to have

888.59.text:
that interaction or that close
personal friendship

890.59.text:
to where you can understand
that perspective.

893.53.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: From a rational
perspective it is hard

895.80.text:
to ask people to care about
what they don’t know about.

899.03.text:
OOSAHWEE: Right.
I think, yeah, it is exposure.

901.03.text:
Expose yourself and talk to
other people.

903.90.text:
Because if you don’t know,
you don’t know.

906.44.text:
I mean if you
never have that.

907.71.text:
But if you were exposed
to this, it’s like,

911.24.text:
and what are you going
to do with that?

913.18.text:
Do you sit with it or do you
try to do something different?”

914.88.text:
It might not be something
that happens right away

916.52.text:
but maybe a couple of
weeks down the line,

920.72.text:
“You know so and so
said this to me,

921.99.text:
and I am thinking about
it more,

923.92.text:
and now I want to
know more.”

925.39.text:
But if you have never
had to be exposed to it

926.89.text:
there’s- I can totally
understand how that happens.

929.30.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: A lot of people
who are involved

930.76.text:
in social activism, social
equity in one way or another,

932.97.text:
talk about maybe a period
about a decade ago

936.27.text:
where it felt that some
of these goals

938.04.text:
that were worth obtaining
were just within reach.

944.34.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: And a lot of
those folks feel that

946.08.text:
really in the last decade that
the goals seem

947.98.text:
maybe to have slipped a
little further away,

952.85.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: Do you
subscribe to that?

954.35.text:
I mean are we in a dark age in
terms of social equity?

956.66.text:
OOSAHWEE: I don’t think we
are in a dark age.

958.29.text:
I think we are in an age where
we are being-

959.99.text:
we are seeing more of some
of these issues

964.96.text:
We were able to, I
think kind of hide them,

966.57.text:
and this election has
been so decisive,

968.27.text:
so many things are coming
up that we thought

969.57.text:
had either been dealt
with or aren’t understanding,

971.30.text: so I think it is something

972.81.text:
that has been brought to the
surface more so.

974.74.text:
I don’t want to believe
we are in a dark point

977.24.text:
because I just have
to feel that there is hope

978.58.text:
and that we are
moving forward

979.75.text:
and something good can
come of it.

982.22.text:
So, you know, I don’t know but
I was listening -

984.25.text:
I actually had the opportunity
to hear Coates speak at

986.49.text:
you know, Between
the World and Me.

987.69.text:
I was at a session and he was
speaking in D.C.

989.79.text:
but you know they mentioned
all of these issues

995.26.text:
that we are trying
to fight against.

996.63.text:
Generations of genocide, and
policies of assimilation

1000.00.text:
It is not going to change
overnight,

1001.83.text:
and it is not going to be
one person.

1004.07.text:
It is not going to be
one idea.

1005.77.text:
There is no silver bullet to
fix everything.

1007.41.text:
Like, there is not one thing
that will make it all better

1009.21.text:
because there are so many
pieces of this puzzle

1011.68.text:
that have to be fixed and
changed on every layer.

1015.72.text:
OOSAHWEE: So, I think
understanding that

1018.32.text:
and knowing that change is
going to take a long time.

1021.89.text:
before we can kind of
get to a different place,

1025.52.text:
and give me some
standing like,

1026.76.text:
“you don’t
have to change it all,

1028.13.text:
you don’t have to fix it, it’s
not all on you.”

1029.50.text:
Because I was feeling at that
time like I am not doing enough.

1030.96.text:
I can’t do it all, and just
losing sleep,

1032.43.text:
and you know, what am I
going to do?

1034.37.text:
There is nothing
that I can do right now

1037.57.text:
but knowing that it
is going to take time

1040.07.text: and I can’t do it all

1041.47.text:
has really kind of
allowed myself to rest

1044.71.text:
I guess from the pressures
that I was feeling.

1046.65.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: Let me just
ask you

1049.65.text:
I mean, given how obvious
it is that racial inequity

1051.88.text:
is a major problem in
the United States-

1056.36.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: Why isn’t there
more national conversation,

1059.76.text:
where we are at least chipping
away at some of these issues

1061.83.text:
and making some
kind of progress,

1063.43.text:
or maybe you
are seeing conversations

1065.23.text: that I am not aware of.

1068.90.text:
I think a lot of it is
education.

1070.90.text:
We are not exposed
to this.

1073.37.text: It is not something that is -

1075.11.text:
we don’t get taught a
proper history.

1077.74.text:
SEDELTA OOSAHWEE: So, we
assume that we know

1079.88.text:
the creation story, it almost
a myth of America

1082.58.text:
You know, they came
over, they were persecuted,

1088.45.text:
OOSAHWEE: And this is
really a beautiful story

1090.22.text:
and you know George
Washington was this great person

1094.83.text:
but there are all of these
other dynamics of these men

1096.43.text:
that we don’t talk about
when we talk about history.

1097.76.text:
And so, we’re not learning the
real history of this country.

1100.43.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: Maybe the play
Hamilton just a little bit

1103.70.text: does open up some of that.

1105.97.text:
Just because these are
demigods, these are -

1109.51.text:
OOSAHWEE: These are actual
human beings who are flawed.

1110.81.text:
OOSAHWEE: But we have
kind of created them

1112.14.text:
into these deities
of almost to a degree of like

1113.95.text:
they are larger than life
mythical human beings

1115.95.text:
and all good,
and they are not.

1118.02.text:
They are like any
human being.

1119.99.text:
They have good.
They have bad.

1121.22.text:
They have flaws, and they were
working under pretenses

1125.63.text:
But, I think education is a
key piece of it,

1127.63.text:
but I think that the
discussion of race and racism

1129.63.text:
is a moral discussion
that the-

1133.57.text:
we frame in that way
and it is not.

1135.77.text:
You know, your either good
people can’t be racist,

1139.97.text: And if you are bad, you are.

1141.64.text:
And it is a good or bad thing,
and it is not.

1143.48.text:
It is a whole institutional
systemic thing happening,

1145.24.text:
and we don’t talk about it
in those ways.

1146.71.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: Is the issue
maybe of white privilege

1148.41.text:
and just white unawareness of
white privilege an issue?

1155.39.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: Because, I can
remember moments

1157.32.text:
in the Obama administration
where the President,

1159.29.text:
who was you know, was a very
sophisticated person,

1162.09.text:
and really aware of a lot of
things going on in the culture,

1164.23.text:
and you could see him
sort of tip toe up to something

1169.97.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: Because he knew
there weren’t hearers

1171.30.text: for what he needed to say.

1172.47.text:
Is that, or just a lot of
conversations that don’t happen

1174.14.text:
because we are all afraid of the
sensibilities of white people

1178.11.text:
that don’t want
the finger pointed at them?

1182.72.text: I think that is a big part of it

1184.78.text:
and I think the word "privilege"
throws a lot of people off

1186.59.text:
because I think we frame it and
the way they think of privilege

1188.49.text:
is kind of in this
monetary financial,

1190.29.text:
“I didn’t grow up
with a lot of money,

1193.76.text:
and that is not
really what we are talking about

1195.63.text:
and so when they
hear that they shut off

1197.50.text:
and they don’t want to
hear anything else

1199.03.text:
or the conversation stops
or becomes confrontational.

1200.70.text:
I also think that there is a
fear of blame.

1202.37.text:
You know, this isn’t a
blame game.

1204.40.text:
This isn’t you did this,
or you did that.

1206.27.text:
It is like, how do
we start talking

1210.48.text:
and get to a place of
better understanding?

1211.94.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: That is a
tough one.

1213.21.text:
I’ve seen that come up a lot
where people will say,

1215.11.text:
"well I don’t want to be made
to feel guilty."

1219.92.text:
it was so long ago,
and it is not me."

1221.29.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: And somebody
needs to just say,

1222.79.text:
“It is not about you, but it
is our common history.”

1224.06.text:
We need to talk
about that, yeah.

1227.49.text:
And I think, I
actually have spoken

1230.76.text:
to different student
groups over the last year

1234.63.text:
and the first part of
it is this history piece.

1237.17.text:
These are some of the
major themes

1239.31.text:
of an era of tribal policy with
the United States Government.

1245.91.text:
and I know the kids
are probably like,

1248.85.text:
But I said that I need
you to understand this

1250.38.text:
so we can understand
where we are at today.

1251.95.text:
So, the work I did, I worked
with 567 tribes.

1254.09.text:
This is the demographics of
the community I worked with.

1256.66.text:
We had people who live in
L.A. and New York, Chicago.

1260.96.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: Was this when
you were with the USCA,

1263.30.text:
OOSAHWEE: Part of it was
during the USCA,

1266.23.text:
part of it was earlier
this year

1268.17.text:
when I was taking some
time off.

1270.57.text:
OOSAHWEE: But, it was just
understanding,

1271.80.text:
we are all- we are in
these cities

1274.24.text:
We have these school
systems called the BIE school

1276.64.text:
and just trying to have them
understand

1277.74.text: all of the systems at play

1278.98.text:
and how history brought us
to this point in time,

1280.11.text:
so to connect
them to that.

1281.51.text:
I grew up in Oklahoma
because of the relocation

1283.48.text:
and because of the
removal act.

1286.09.text:
OOSAHWEE: That directly
impacted me and my family.

1287.82.text:
You, as people living here in
New York,

1290.86.text:
you came here and your family
has their own story

1295.36.text:
Whether they are things
that happened

1297.23.text:
in other
parts of the world

1298.56.text:
or here in the
United States

1299.83.text:
that brought you to this
place in time

1301.17.text:
and you have to
understand that.

1302.50.text:
I also wanted them to know
that we look at history

1303.77.text:
in numbers and it’s really
easy to not,

1305.10.text:
like on the Trail of Tears
4,000 Cherokees died.

1308.87.text:
This is just a number
to them.

1310.54.text:
But it’s like when you just
start thinking that

1315.31.text:
That was a mother, a father,
that was a child,

1317.78.text:
an aunt, there is all of
these.

1320.19.text:
They were all individual people,
but that is devastating,

1324.89.text:
and we just think
of it in this,

1326.29.text:
that was so long ago
and now is now,

1327.93.text:
but it all connects to where
we are at now.

1329.86.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: You,
you make such a good point

1331.26.text:
about change is
going to really be at many

1333.80.text:
different levels in many
parts of the culture, etc.

1336.27.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: This would just
seem to be a situation

1337.77.text:
that is so obviously calls

1339.51.text:
Somebody to lead

1344.04.text:
and be encouraging to
people that they-

1350.62.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: It is not going
to devastate them.

1353.19.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: We can learn
about our history.

1355.72.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: I am just-
I am not even sure

1358.42.text:
Why don’t we have those
leaders?

1361.43.text:
Where would you think they
might come from?

1362.83.text:
We just seem to need that

1365.70.text:
OOSAHWEE: Yeah. We
do, and I am not really-

1367.93.text:
that answer is one that I am
not really sure about either.

1370.00.text: I mean there are so many.

1371.30.text:
I don’t know if it is a

1373.84.text:
I don’t know if it needs to be

1376.98.text:
It’s nice to have that

1378.58.text:
or place to look,
but I don’t really know

1384.22.text:
where we have these people
that might not just be one

1386.55.text:
but collectives of
people that can do that.

1388.22.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: The National
Conference of Race and Ethnicity

1390.59.text:
where people come
from all over the country

1394.73.text:
OOSAHWEE: Yes, they have these

1399.23.text:
and then they go out
and try to spread that word

1400.83.text:
to where they go so
maybe it’s these places

1402.64.text:
where we all come
together and have time

1404.34.text:
to have these
conversations and refuel

1406.37.text:
because I
think we need that,

1410.24.text:
and then go out and try
to teach other people

1411.74.text: and bring other people on board

1413.05.text:
so next year bring
more people with you

1414.45.text:
so that we can have
more people going out

1415.75.text:
and having these
conversations and doing this.

1417.65.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: A lot of
leaders at a lower level.

1420.25.text:
OOSAHWEE: Not just this
one kind of person or these,

1422.12.text:
because I think that is
how we look at leadership

1424.76.text:
Like you know, even with the
President,

1427.93.text:
I think, you know, there is
this idea that this one person

1431.13.text:
and I think it needs to be a
lot of people doing this work

1433.13.text:
and I don’t think it
can change

1434.90.text:
without a lot of people
doing the work.

1436.30.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: If you were
Queen of the World for a day,

1437.84.text:
and could do whatever
you wanted.

1439.20.text:
What two or three changes
would you do that,

1441.47.text:
would you make that
you felt

1445.74.text:
OOSAHWEE: Um, I think
one would be

1451.42.text:
No more one person in charge
of everything.

1456.99.text:
OOSAHWEE: And I think two
would be I would love to see

1458.86.text:
our history taught in a way
that is more reflective

1462.86.text:
Because I think that would
help us

1464.66.text:
maybe understand each other
a little bit better.

1467.20.text:
It’s not going to change
everything,

1469.94.text:
but I think if we
can at least be honest

1471.24.text:
about where we have
come from,

1474.27.text:
and our history is
not always beautiful.

1481.48.text:
There are so many things,
and it is hard.

1486.92.text:
Our history if painful and I
think growth is painful.

1488.19.text:
I think maybe that is
one of the reasons

1489.62.text:
why we have so many
people who are afraid

1492.69.text:
because it means looking
at things

1494.19.text:
and seeing things differently
and any kind of growth,

1497.46.text:
It is a very painful, painful
thing to do,

1499.93.text:
and I don’t think a lot of
people really want to do that

1502.53.text:
especially if you know you are
struggling just to get by.

1504.67.text:
I am worried about putting
food on my table.

1507.21.text:
I don’t have time to think
about, you know,

1508.97.text:
anything else going
on around me.

1512.51.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: Right, but it
would be liberating.

1514.05.text:
It would bring us together as
a community.

1515.51.text:
It would expose them to
different ideas

1519.12.text:
“Oh, so that’s why" I have a
better understanding

1521.19.text:
of how these people
are living here

1523.79.text:
and the cycle
of poverty continues,

1525.72.text:
because now I understand
redlining or I understand,

1527.36.text:
you know the
segregations of schools

1533.10.text:
ann the actual real life
outcomes of that.

1535.93.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: Would you look
into your crystal ball,

1537.57.text:
you are still Queen by
the way.

1541.34.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: Look
into your crystal ball

1544.38.text:
and tell us something
that you think,

1545.71.text:
you personally believe is
likely to happen

1547.31.text:
that will have an
impact on racial equity

1549.28.text:
maybe for tribal peoples
in the United States

1552.18.text:
good or bad, but something
on the horizon

1554.32.text:
you think is kind
of waiting out there for us.

1556.19.text:
OOSAHWEE: I think what is
happening is,

1557.92.text:
you know with this last
election,

1561.16.text:
we have so many people
we are saying,

1562.80.text:
“I want to run for office, I
want to know more about this,

1566.53.text:
So, I think we are going to
see an influx of, you know,

1573.44.text:
you know politicians who are
from different communities

1578.98.text:
and learning about the system
that is so complicated

1581.11.text:
to help improve the
lives of their communities

1583.02.text:
and others and
everyone around them.

1584.85.text:
So, I think there is going to
be an influx of that.

1586.62.text:
I am hopeful; I am so
hopeful it happens.

1588.25.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: You know,
actually that makes

1591.59.text:
I can see why you say that
because there are periods

1592.86.text:
in American history of
awakenings where there was

1594.53.text:
something that was
really challenging of a culture

1596.46.text:
and in response to
that a lot of people have

1599.33.text:
to define their values
and kind of double down,

1602.20.text:
and it sounds like
you are saying

1604.67.text:
that out of the
current period

1606.17.text:
we are going to
see some kind of renewal.

1609.11.text:
It was a reality check for so
many, and they said,

1610.48.text:
“Well what am I doing
and how can I do more?”

1611.94.text:
And I think they recognized
that they are waiting

1613.51.text: for other people to come in

1614.95.text:
and I had to talk about
an experience recently

1616.88.text:
and I was like I think we
keep waiting for someone

1618.32.text:
to come in and save
us and say

1619.72.text:
that this is wrong
and that’s right,

1621.19.text:
and you come to this
realization

1622.99.text:
that sometimes you
have to save yourself

1624.52.text:
and so you have to
be that person

1625.69.text:
that steps forward and
makes that decision-

1626.99.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: You may
be the only one

1632.46.text:
OOSAHWEE: And then by doing so
you help other people

1635.17.text:
DAVIS-UNDIANO: Sedelta
Oosahwee thank you so much

1636.70.text:
for doing the show.
You were wonderful.

Thank you for taking the time
